thread.title: LOOK: Kansas City police determine call against Royals was a 'crime'
thread.title_full: LOOK: Kansas City police determine call against Royals was a 'crime' - CBSSports.com

author: Matt Snyder
title: LOOK: Kansas City police determine call against Royals was a 'crime'
text:
In a pivotal moment during Game 4 of the Royals - Astros ALDS, Royals pinch runner Terrance Gore stole third. He was the tying run (it was 3-2 Astros at the time) and was just 90 feet away. At least that's how it looked. The Astros ended up challenging the call and it was ruled that as Gore was popping up, he lost contact with the bag and was tagged out.
Here's the video and a screen-shot:
Your browser does not support iframes. 
This was at least more clear than the Odor play in game 2. pic.twitter.com/zU0fJJOkrX 
— Jason Collette (@jasoncollette) October 12, 2015 Note that Luis Valbuena only appears to be tagging Gore with his wrist. That in addition to the fact that Gore was separated from the bag for roughly a split second caused lots of uproar on social media, predictably.
The Kansas City Police were involved ...
That call on Gore was a crime.
— Kansas City Police (@kcpolice) October 12, 2015 Always good to maintain a sense of humor in the face of anger over a baseball game.
That call ended up being buried under a three-run Astros' seventh that pushed the lead to 6-2 with the Royals only six outs away from being eliminated. Talk about a gut punch to the defending AL champs.
Topics: Luis Valbuena , Terrance Gore , Houston Astros , Kansas City Royals , MLB
